projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: EPIGRAMS and sentences spirituall in vers, of GREGORI NAZANZEN, an auncient & famous Bishop in the Greke churche: Englished by Tho. Drant.
Imprinted at London in fletestreate, neare vnto S. Dunstones church by Thomas Marshe. 1568.

div.head: To the righte honorable, the right reuerent father in God Edmonde Bishoppe of London, his very good Lorde and Maister, Tho. Drant wisheth grace and peace with long and ioyful life, in the euerliuing God through Christe our Sauiour.
div.p: PErusing (right honorable) some of the Germaine wryters, and delighting in their pretie & wittie verses, which to the texts and common places of holy scriptures they fitly haue applied: I founde no sayinges in them of a more quicke and godly sence, then those whiche they bringe oute of Gregorie Nazanzen, a Doctour of the Gréeke churche very wel learned, and very eloquent. Basil the great hath called him the Uessell of election, the profounde fountaine, the mouthe of Christe. Baptist Mantuan thus wryteth in his commendation.

q.l: Gregorius, cui dat diuina scientia tantum
Nomen, adest, hodie sacros habiturus honores
Praesule patre satus (nam tunc id iura sinebant)
Pastorale pedum gessit post funera patris
By Zantina tulit faustos in menia gressus.
Fama viri traxit varijs ex gentibus agmen
Nam quot erant toto orbe viri, qui scire profundos
Et Cabilistarum latebras, ea littora adibant,
Hieronymum fama est illuc veuisse trilinguem
Et legis didicisse sub hoc arcana magistro.

div.p:
Amongest the reste his woorkes those sentences, and Epigrams which are called spiritual, are so in dede as they are called. They moue the spirite, in mouinge delight it, & that with an excellent and choise kinde of delectation. Beinge thus brought into a booke, the booke is small: and, a pearle is smal likewise, but if it were much bigger or better, it would make me the gladder. That these fewe sayinges of Gregorie Nazanzen should be to your L. addressed (as the doinges of a learned father to a learned father) that is of congruitie: that from me to your L. that is of my dutie.
Neither doe I recke, or recken howe great it is, but howe great, and good I would haue it to be. Neither is it as a thinge in it selfe able to showe my good wyll: be it therefore as an argument that if I had better wherewith, I would haue ben right willing to haue shewed it. This humbly crauing I cease to trouble you. The .x. of Aprill.

closer.signed: Your Lordships to be commaunded Tho. Drant.

div.head: De Gregorio ad Lectores.
div.l: Haec cecinit Graia carmina sancta lyra,
Gregorius rectè, non ille Gregarius, ergo
Hunc summè summi sic coluere sophi.
Graecia magna suū magnū nunc versat alumnū,

Si populo pietas, religio
que siet,
Haud fuit, haud nūc est, credo nec esse potest.
Vix vidit quidq praeclarius auricomus sol,
Spectetis numeros, numeris vel numen in ipsis,

Omne tulit punctum, iudicium
que bonum.

lg.l: (Est 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 tua sic cignia 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 )
Et dum manna fluit faucibus inclytis:

Laetis, at
que bonis aedite saeculis.

div.head: W. C. Doctor, to the translation.

lg.l: SOme venture farre with litle skill
Whose stuffe is good, but working ill,
Some goodly giftes on matters grosse
Whose metall base the workemen staynes,
Sometyme fine workemen of the best
They frame a worke of great renowme
Such is this booke: her golden gifte
A worthy worke, and workeman fyne

div.head: Tvvo kindes of life, Actiue, and Contemplatiue.
div.l: Whiche lyfe of twayne doth better seame to thee,
That whiche is bent to outwarde exercise:
Or that which still contemplatiue would be?
The one loue mo, the other the more wyse.
Both this, and that are pleasaunt like and fit,
But what is fit for the, best like thou it.

div.head: Trie thy selfe, before thou intermedle with holy matters.
div.l: A ghostly question one of me did aske,
Hast thou examined well thy selfe (quod I)
Els doest thou but attempt a sinful taske,
I am cleane purified (quod he) pardy.
For who is he that hath not lost his witte,
Newe oyle to vessels olde that wyl committe?

div.head: Truste not lightly nor cauill muche.
div.l: All manner wordes, or promis doe not truste,
Against eache speache, in no wyse maist thou mell,
But as through tyme, and place thou rightly must,
Obey thou God, whom thou canst not excell.
With mouthe all men most egrely doe striue:
With manners neuer one that is aliue.

div.head: A shame for a teacher to be reprouable.
div.l: Or neuer teache thou any any worde at all,
Or els with manners doe the same expresse:
Least one hande buylde, the other make to fall.
The better lyfe, of wordes it neades the lesse:
We iudge a Painter so to be of skyll,
Euen as his workemanship is good, or ill.

div.head: Let Bishops, and Prelates geue light.
div.l: O you that Lordlike rule so sterne, and stoute,
Whose wealth, and worship stretcheth farre, and wyde:
Take hede your lyncks, and lanterns go not out,
Least wycked Prelates you at last be tryde,
If light be darke, that was so bright, and trimme,
What wylbe darkenes of it selfe so dimme?

div.head: VVel doing is better then wel saying.
div.l: A speacheles deede doth passe a deedeles worde.
Without good deedes fewe haue ben caught vp hie,
But those whiche finest phrase could not aforde,
Doe naithelesse alday skale vp to the skie,
Not of the babling speaker god hath neade,
But of the soule, that workes his will in deade.

div.head: An acceptable offring vnto God.
div.l: Most welcome gift to God is manners pure,
Though thou to him couldst all the world present,
The gift is not so good, thy selfe assure,
Before all giftes good life doth him content.
Geue him thy harte, as doe the meake, that quake,
Thy coyne (an horishe bribe) God wyl not take.

div.head: Make no vowe to God.
div.l: Make thou no vowe not in the smalest thing,
Thou guyles thy selfe to crake that that is thyne
Which was gods owne, before thou diddes it bring.
That from indebted vs we should decline,
May warne vs well in this our mortall life,
The death of Ananias and his wyfe.

div.head: Mans life a market.
div.l: Beleue this life to be a very marte,
Great gaine there is if thou wilt plie a whyle,
Eternall thinges for vayne thou maist by arte
Exchaunge: and dearest ware for chaffer vile:
But if thou slougge, and loiter liuing here,
No other tyme, hereafter wyl appeare.

div.head: The race of Christian life.
div.l: Farre must we runne in this our drery race,
But more shalbe our guardon great in tyme,
Take hede thou hast not so the whole timbrace
That of the whole thou mis with note of cryme.
The deuill that would vs all from ioye exempt▪
On both handes thus doth vse the good to tempte.

div.head: Nor presume, nor dispaire.
div.l: Truste not to muche, ne yet to much dispayre,
The one doth make vs dissolutely to bolde,
That other leades to euerlasting care,
Correcte the last, and firme the former holde,
Arighte: and freely fare vpon thy waye
Not enuie pale, not malice neade thee staie.

div.head: Kepe on thy course in vertue.
div.l: Proceade in thinges with good aduise begonne,
To moue at first makes not a good mans state,
But still to moue vntill the thing be done,
For we doe counte him curste, and worthy hate,
Not who a litil downwarde slippes awry,
But he that falles exalted once on hie.

div.head: All occasion of euill is to be shunned.
div.l: A prety sparke doth rayse a mightie flame,
A Uipers seade doth pestilently kyll,
Instructed well, and warned by this same,
Eschewe the smalest blot of any ill:
For being soylde with blemishe very small,
It draweth daungers manifolde with all.

div.head: Knowe thy selfe. Good deedes better then golde.
div.l: Thine owne affaires looke rather thou applie
Then to thy neighbours busily attende:
Thy neighbour he may some thing get thereby,
The other would thine owne estate amende.
Good deedes are better muche then fee, or golde,
The one decaye, the other stande, and holde.

div.head: Study godlines: Charme thy tongue.
div.l: To sacred reade thy mynde deuout dispose,
And to the rules deuine of blessed life,
Thy tatling tongue let it not glide, or glose,
In bablarie, or blablarie too rife,
Whiche if at randome thou permit to walke,
I warrant thee no wynner by thy talke.

div.head: Temptation by thy eies.
div.l: Our sight would gladly carie vs away.
But by resisting tho it is represt,
We are not booteys for syr Cupides pay,
No idole myndes to him we haue Idrest:
The baite was faire disguist, but we are gonne,
Of Satans snares, this certainly was one▪

div.head: Temptation by the eares.
div.l: Gainst wanton talke thyne eares with waxe doe shitte,
And against all sonneites delicate, and softe,
But what so for an honest man is fitte,
That thou respectiuly must very ofte
Both marke with diligent, and hedie care,
And in thy saws and deedes the same declare:

div.head: Temptation by the other senses.
div.l: To odours womannishe, and fragrant smell,
Thy selfe to tender touchinges doe not yealde,
If these doe maister thee, what wilt thou well
Deserue with hande in battayle champion fielde?
The man hath his peculiar proper prayse:
The woman hirs by other diffring wayes.

div.head: Be not to liberal to thy belly.
div.l: Still geue me, geue me, crithe the gredy paunche,
And haue thou shalt, if well thou canst it saue,
But if in dunge it passeth by the haunche
Eftsones, what bootes it thee so much to haue?
If thou dost kepe it long to make it more:
Of dunge thou dost but treasure greater store.

div.head: Laughter must be laughed at.
div.l: Uaine laughter would be laughed at againe,
To laughe whyles down thy chekes the teares at rolde,
And better is a sadde, and pewly face,
Then that which smileth smugge with smirking grace.

div.head: Fauour and deformitie.
div.l: True beautie doth adorne a godly mynde,
And is to it a furniture, (no doubte)
No furniture which tyme can chaunge from kynde,
Nor such as crafte of hande can braue set out,
The mynde not practisde doth deformed lye,
As spieth he which hath an inwarde eye.

div.head: Contempte of vanities.
div.l: Fearcenesse, and feare, let them both flitte, and flye,
Without regarde to where they would begonne:
Such thinges so tickle, fickle, vile, and vayne,
Doe nothing moue a suerly setled brayne.

div.head: The highnesse and humblenesse of good vvorkes.
div.l: Be hie, not in thyne owne conceite at all,
For that with sodayne swaye wyll cast the downe,
If els thou buylst to hie, loke for a fall,
Be hie in vpright lyfe, that wyl thee crowne:
The more that thou exalted art on hie,
The lesse stande thou on thy maioritie.

div.head: Against vayne glorie and dissimulation.
div.l: Nor thou eche prayse, nor too much prayse persue,
Its wurst to be accompted then to bee,
Flie praise which sprynges by gaie fonde facions newe
(In case thou knowest not measure in degree)
An Ape is he not still a very Ape,
Though all men iudge he hath a Lions shape?

div.head: Take not pryde in prayse, Prayse not rashly.
div.l: If others praysing vardit make thee proude,
Thou shalt be thought a prayser for to want,
And rynging out an others prayses loude,
His manners hauing yet seruaid skant,
If his demenour be perceyued ill:
Thy credit that will quyte destroy, and spyll.

div.head: Pleasure not in deriding an other.
div.l: Its better much to beare a scoffe, or scorne:
Then thee thy selfe to skorne, and scoffe,
If that vncyuilly thou byst not torne,
Thy vantage is with bourde to beare it of.
So shall this mery mockyng kynde of glee,
Unto the mocker moste vnpleasaunt bee.

div.head: Triumphe ouer no man.
div.l: Eere that thou commes to port, boast not thy gayle,
For many men vpon the very shore,
Haue wrecke their shippe, and sunke adown their sayle:
And many midst thicke wrastling waues Ibore
Haue safe aryvde vpon the sedicke coast,
To laughe at no mans chaunce is wysdome most.

div.head: Better clere conscience in aduersitie, then feare of iudgement in vvelth.
div.l: So that thou lyvst in righteous manner here,
Though vndersoote, and subiect vnto throws
Prostrat to God in prayre, and conscience clere,
If that thou byst, and him sincerely knowes:
Its better then berest of grace to smart,
Though all the worlde were framed to thy harte.

div.head: Almesse measure.
div.l: Whatsoeuer goodes thou hast the same disburse,
That thou the lorde of life maist thyne possesse,
That is not thyne which now is in thy purse,
If that thou givst not all giue litle lesse,
If so to giue doe cast thee into care:
Be free of that which safely thou maist spare.

div.head: Almesse dealing.
div.l: From mouthes, and malice to the neady poore,
If thou at any tyme doste ought withhould,
Christe is thy debter it for to restore
Who doth his heauenly kyngdome (more then goulde)
Giue for a curste of bread: and all thy who
Doe cladde the poore, doe cladde our sauiour (lo)

div.head: As vve are affected to the poore, so is Christe to vs.
div.l: A poore man came to me in miserable case,
And emptie went away nought hauing gotte,
O Christe I wretched man deuoire of grace,
Doe feare lest by the very selfe same lote
I part from thee, he that doth small dispence,

div.head: Godly pouertie is to be relieued.
div.l: The substance smale doth make the harte full light,
The poore man sighes, and sories much his case,
But vpon God he bendes his total sight,
This poore man thou deare in thyne armes imbrace:
The Egle in her neast (we reade it oft)
A litle straunger byrde wyll harboure softe.

div.head: Pouertie better then ill gotten riches.
div.l: Its better styll to lyue in hardest neede
Then ryche to waxe by trecherie, and guyle,
So sicknesse better is then health with speade
That daungerous coms, and flittes within a whyle.
With hunger no man sodenly doth die::
Sinne kylleth, and condemneth by and by.

div.head: A seruaunt is a felovve seruaunt.
div.l: Maister and man, why doe we vse to saye?
One head, one lawe we haue, and eke one iudge,
Thy seruaunt thou thy felowe seruaunt aye
To call and count doe then in no wyse grudge:
So thou thy selfe a maister franke, and free,
Of freedome thine shall worthy counted be.

div.head: No shame to be a seruaunt.
div.l: Seruauntes? why not? chiefly gods seruauntes tho
Unto their maisters let them truly meane.
A freman, or a seruaunt, ye, or no
By that we knowe as he doth hym demeane:
Our sauiour Christe that did infranch is all,
To humble seruice did him selfe inthrall.

div.head: True nobilitie.
div.l: A shame it is not to be base, but badde,
From those whose sithens longe are lodged in claye
The glorie of thy gentrie thou hast had.
To helpe thy stocke not hurt it, is the waye.
Its better thee to bee a godly brode,
Then childe to those whiche godly be, and good.

div.head: Christe thrists to be thristed after.
div.l: Thou only God, and godly thinges desire,
Who more will giue, the more that thou wilt take,
Full of all giftes what so thou wilt require,
And thrists for to be thristed for thy sake,
In other thinges if happely thou doest misse,
That doe, and kepe which iust, and measure is.

div.head: Cast not alwaies to ouercome.
div.l: Not alwayes looke to ouercome thy foe,
Nor there about doe beate, and bruse thy brayne,
He wynnes sometime that lettes the maistrie goe,
And gettes at lenght more full, and noble gaine.
The champion oft is daunted dead from hie:
And he doth lyne that lurking lowe doth lye.

div.head: Some losse bringes vantage.
div.l: It vantage thinke to suffer any losse,
That tree wilbe more fruitfull then before,
That hath lost both his thicket bowes, and mosse:
To goodes ill gotte who styll doth heape vp more,
Let him adde fyer to tymber tunder drie,
Or to his body adde a malady.

div.head: Forget and forgiue.
div.l: If vnto God thou byst indebted nought,
Thy debter then in no wyse doe thou spare.
But if thy debtes by hunderds be in brought,
First to forgiue let be thy spedie care.
So God in suche a charitable case
Will recompence thee plentie grace for grace.

div.head: In iniuries call to minde Christe his passion.
div.l: If wrong receyvde doe wrast thy mynde to yre,
Then call to mynde his woundes ibroched kene,
What wrong had he vniustly for his hire
That once our maister must aloft be sene?
His bleding woundes, and moisture of the same
Will moist, and quenche the fearcenesse of thy flame.

div.head: The chastning of thy body is a medicine for vice.
div.l: Wyne, lust, enuie, and Satan are all one,
Whom they possesse, the same they doe oppresse▪
Teares, hunger, prayers, are deemed fit alone▪
And meadsons meete the same for to redresse.
So I those griefes doe vse for to asswage,
So staye I them, and rule them in their rage.

div.head: Sweare not.
div.l: Sweare not, how then? how should I then perswade?
With wordes, and deades which testimony cleare
Doe bring vnto the wordes whiche thou hast saide:
He God denies, which doth him selfe forsweare
What neadst thou God prophane in mouth so rife?
Make vs beleue thee by thyne vpright life.

div.head: The summe of the lawe is charitie, and Christe his passion.
div.l: What rule of loue haue we most short and true?
As thou wouldes wyshe thy neighbours be to thee
Suche one thy selfe vnto thy neighbours shewe,
And such a one looke plainly that thou bee.
Christes passion wayed well doe this conteyne
In full effecte, compendious, and playne.

div.head: A deare frende is a deare treasure.
div.l: Thinke nothing dearer then a faithfull frende,
Not suche as thou hast wonne to thee in wyne.
But suche as trothe in troubles long did lende,
The other will not seke for thee, but thine.
A bridge thyne ire, and sone it ouer sende.
Of frendly loue seke not to make an ende.

div.head: Counsailers are necessary.
div.l: The eye that all thinges spies, it selfe not spies,
If it be blynde, then spies it not in deede
It selfe, nor ought, but blynde, and bluntishe lies:
Of counsaylers we then doe stande in neade,
For so the hande doth (pardie) neade the hande,
And of the foote, the foote in neede doth stande.

div.head: Backbiting, shamefastnesse.
div.l: If thou the good, and godly doest obay,
And listned hast, and leande to their behest,
Let the vngodly say what they can say,
Blushe not to heare them boldly gibe, and ieste
If any filthie acte thou haste in mynde,
Thinke thousandes stande before thee, and behinde.

div.head: Good companie.
div.l: Preferre the good before the wicked sort,
The godly eke before thee godlesse route,
Ill shalt thou be to ill if thou resorte.
A wicked man no good can bring aboute.
Suche one as gettes his goodes by wicked wayes.
And by expending them doth gape for prayse.

div.head: Frutes of fooes.
div.l: Some profite I can take, yea by my foe,
By shunning him, and dreading him eche where,
I beare my selfe more wary where I goe.
A bitter medson much we ought to teare,
Yet of the sweate that makes the pallate faine,
More cause we haue ofttymes for to complaine.

div.head: Pacience breakes enuie.
div.l: Honour the good, contempne the lawlesse lewde,
For that they be inormouse lyvde in cryme,
Whom prayse thou not whilst still they be so shrewde
But them conuert in pacience, and time,
This is the bountie most, the gift most franke,
That thou canst giue, and worthy most of thanke.

div.head: The measure of bounty.
div.l: Be liberal to the vtmoste of thy power
In tyme, and place so farre as store wil strech,
Unto thy neyghbour do thy kind deuoure
Ther of the reason is not farre to fetche,
To straungers who will thinke that thou art kinde,
When to thyne owne vngratefull they thee finde?

div.head: Blame our selues, not the deuill.
div.l: Why doe we blame the Deuill? why doe we so?
Why doe we morne, that he doth make vs sinne?
Our liues at randone louse why let we go?
The fault or hoallie we, or chiefe are in.
In this our fleshe the fier we beare aboute:
The feende doth blowe to make the flame flashe out.

div.head: Dreames vaine.
div.l: Beleue not dreames, let them not thee deceiue,
Nor let eche fearfull fansie the agriese,
If that thou happe some vision gladde to haue,
Be thou not proude therof in any wyse,
Suche folishe fraude, and fonde delightfull pelfe
From Satan comes, euen from his very selfe.

div.head: Hope the beste.
div.l: To all thy deedes a prosprous ende propounde,
For if that God to doinges whiche be ill
No hinderer, but a suffrer oft be founde:
The acte thats good (no doubt) he furder will:
Though ill thee good doe seame for to appall
Yet ill at length shall finde, and feele the fall.

div.head: Learning and vvisedome.
div.l: Wisedome is safer thing then prosprous lucke,
Fortune doth faune, and sclender stroke doth yealde,
But witte, and wysedome giue the stronger plucke,
And only they doe rule in towne and fielde.
Learning doth passe the brightest gift of mynde,
A surer treasure shal we neuer finde.

div.head: Stoutenesse, and courage.
div.l: Be stoute, and sterne, but not in deades iniust,
If thou wilt be gods dearling deare, and childe,
But when thy case is good, and needes thou must,
Let dastarde feare, and dreede be quite exilde,
Theirs manye ils thats causers of decaye,
The hemlocke, and the Scorpion poyson paie.

div.head: An olde man vvithout vvitte, a younge vvithout courage.
div.l: A yonge man lesse of courage then an olde,
An olde man then a yonge man lesse of witte,
Unsitting and vnsemely both we holde,
The age doth make the vertue kyndly fitte.
Let him be wyse as sone as he is olde,
And him before his age of courage bolde.

div.head: VVorke and vvatche.
div.l: Eche man in feare, must worke his sauing health,
So muche the more the nearer death doth stande,
Olde age wyl eftsones steppe on vs by stealth,
The trumpet soundes our ende to be at hande:
Be ready therefore all both more, and some,
Be ready (O) the dreadfull iudge doth come.

div.head: VVisedome better then riches.
div.l: A droppe of lucke before a tunne of skill
Giue me (so sayde a bolde curmogine chuffe)
Phy (quoth the learned man) thou pratest ill,
And harke how litle I esteme thy stuffe▪
One droppe of skyll my harte wolde better please,
Then of good lucke an hundred hudgie seas.

div.head: VVe deny God tvvo vvayes.
div.l: In worde and deede, our God we deny,
(So shetteth vp my litle pamflet booke)
The Deuill doth daungerous lurke vnto thee nye,
Not farre from thee, but rounde about the looke.
Thy soule to saue in present longe distresse
Giue euer thankes to God, and blith him blesse.

div.head: Against the Arians, Hipocrites, and disceuers.
div.l: You which both God, and man
You blest to all mens sight,
You are from that as farre,
How so euer thou me calles,
And bids me get me farre,
Yeat what my mynde me giues,
Geue good leue for to speake,
With wordes do chaunce to touche
Are wordes, and of my care,
We tell it as we finde,
To his Christ came at lenght,
He God, and man was heare,
Forth lardge his bloude did streame,
On his worde with their worde,
On bloude with bloude should waite.
Howe commes the mone so darke,
To giue he doth not misse.
Nor stirde them from their state.
The more that they the rage
Her self on rockes doth throwe.
Made euen with grounde in space.
Howe well I will not saye:
The Lorde him selfe I knowe
So now the worst and best,
The Turke with vs is prest.
And in the Churche of Christ
To wher God, and good men
But now it is not rare.
To se howe in they rushe.
Not one with out doth bide.
I thinke some blast of trompe.
Hath breathed vp alowde,A blast of the world to disorder the Churche.
Ye that do steale the shares
That loue to take no skath,
As you would eate them rawe,
To squire them vp and downe.
Take ease with heade on hande
And sturre not from your stall,
All thinges that heare we haue,
Ye shall not neade to doubte
God streight will séende a showre,
And now for your swete sakes,
Eche man may fill his lappe
He more, he lesse, and yf
You thinke it for your paye,
And let it rote at home
The skye, and starres from hye
Ther is a place for Saule.
Let no man haue a guide
Who hath on them in chardge
And he lyues beast at ease
Let him cast downe at once,
The plowgh all from his handes,
A waye his felles and skynnes
Come take you romes vp all
Let eche man place him best,
As he by force is able,
Come thrust, and eke be thrust,
The great to lesse do wronge,
Thrust whilles the stalles go downe,
The best Preyst that is founde,
Suche one as loues the skyes,"
Who thoughe he be in steade
Yet he in synne is deade.
But he that lookes on you,
To paynt you in your kyndes,
Example agaynste rashnes.But Moyses makes me carcke,
They would yeald vp ther bones,
To dartes, to cragges, to rockes,
For feare do make me quake,
To quake, and stande in dread
O Christ, I wéepe, I morne
Still in my charge to toyle,
My mynde doth leaue the corpes,
But now with huffe and snuffe
God is not now their God,
Or he is eche mans God
For men, and not for Christ
So that our Christ in vayne
By stelth she clekes, and glenes,
Nowe pride doth proule for prayse
She wynne not of a flye.
To what so they do preache
They speake not as they thinke,
Or selde, or neuer in one.
Both those whiche haue no guides,
And those which haue suche guides,
And still is like to stande,
That he that is the worst
To them the world giues place,
To them gods selfe giues place,
The wills, and féese of men
Thoughe now we toile in vayne.
Alls one, Christ, man, the starrs,
The sunne, the darke, the lyght,
An ownce, and dramme are one.
And they which with their mockes
The cuers on them did bide
Yée iudge for to be wise,
That shall make all to burne:
I will not take their parte,
I dare not be their mate,
Once will I knowe the state.
We come not in one shippe,
We sayle not in one Bardge,
I will not walke their waye
Nor sincke with them for chardge.
Let them post out the race
To skape that is to come
I will steppe from their pathe,
From path to make vs starte.
I hope to take suche hede
Shall all be donne in sighte.

div.head: The othe of Nazensen being made Bishoppe.
div.l: Which once for mans great loue
Ile chaunge, or with my wordes
Or if I fréet in neade,
And on so weke a helpe
If that in waues of welth,
My mynde be pufte with pride,
Do make me loke more hie,
If I do gibe, or skorne
If that my breast be blinde,
If that my tonge doth talke,
I let a poore man gooe.
If I féede not those brestes
That thrist for Christ his worde:
This is my lawe of lyfe,
Nor thought, nor deade is myne,

div.head: A spirituall dompe.
div.l: Shall great his praise be wrought?
A God shall he vp stande
And doth not from the hole
That in his hart, and mouthe
Still loue, and wit doth dwell?
Who doth not like the waues
Giue boate to these our broyles,
And blesse vs with the best.

div.head: A praier against Iulianus.
div.l: I way it not a rushe,
Thoughe it be blacke and bluddy to,
That fleshborne beast in vgly synne
That fearre our churche doth chase,
That toppe, and tippe of mischeifes all,
Nor all his blades bright brandishing
Thoughe sword: though fier, though bests,
To drowne in deapes, thoughe he alone though he,
Ould tyrannes fell, which beare them brag
To those which earst hath béene,
Of this we haue to force the lesse:
A only meadson we do knowe
Which can not misse the game
Our Christ who so shall dye for him
But inward brech, and cyuill broyle
And quyt excludeth all my force,
My self know not my selfe in trothe,
I wote not what to make.
Ne wote I what confections good
No wyt, no reason, no good gift
No manner armoure gainst the deuill
And wynnes by craft, and treachery.
Shall Moyses preachynge on the mounte
A broad his hands that threwe?
Who leuing them vppon the rocke
And proude the man of God in god
Who alwayes gainst the sayntes of God
Who shall this Moyses next succeade
That of Iesus in name and deade
He ioyninge host with god aboue
And throughe the name of Iesus he
With outwhose helpe we trust in vaine:
Or wright he verse, or cast with slinge
Him god to battayle troubles fell
Some Samuell we wishe for next
At nead to serue our turne,
Upon the alter for the folke
To knele, and pray vpon his knées,
A kynge to noynte a conquerer
Sad Ieremye wold stand in steade
Who writ for Iuishe folke his Threnes
Who prayers for our pardon can
O spare vs God of heauen thrise blest,
Spare vs that feare▪ spare vs thy flocke
Let hym not se our shame,
And let no stranger nation vs
Who ells for vs alyue might praye
In prayer one, in mynde all one
These thre as one maye gooe.
And pray that all this hooly strife
At lenght might pause, and cease,
That we our selfes, might know our selfs,
And ioye our owne in peace:
That one an other frindly knowe,
And that one lynked people we
If Israell we haue bine one,
And one in saith did bide,
Mongst vs No more let be,
We all accuse, but he discerns

div.head: Mariage, Redemption, • eape iudgments of God.
div.l: THe knittinge best of two in one
Of all that we can find
The death of some, and birth of some
A ryuer stands by that that commes,
And fades in that thats gonne.
But after that all coastes of the yearth
Whence winds from East, weast, North, & Sowth
The sonnes of men had ouer spred:
With heat of sin, then plangs cam one
And men their skourge did trye.
Then cam the tables, and their texts
But all this chast not synne awaye,
It to the fleshe was tyde
To them from hie was sent,
From God the father, and the sonne
For God which did mens bodyes vew
That man was seruant to the féende:
To coule so ferce a fitt
To other nowe the cuers therof,
Great soores, great salues. him selfe came downe,
Of heauenly syer, an heauenly prynce
Mongst men man was he borne.
In sinne not man: (which some thinke not,
Ye came flesh forth the virgins wombe
Both God he came, and man he came,
This spied, that hid: a carnall man
One God, one Christ, one man of God,
The first we did despise in him
I onc receyud this heauenly soule:
Christ toke both corps, and ghost
First Adame had his wil to chose,
Eternall death for him, and vs
For him that should haue better sene
And was for holy things a Préest
Him to redeme our God was glad
His armes out strechd and vnto hym
Drewe all men with that power
In that one man, and with his bludde
And vnto vs set open heauen
That to that hooly vpright hill
O kynge who can seke out thy sence,
That knowes the windes, the droppes of showers
And sands of al the ground.
Who can thy secret steppes bewray
Almightie that dost all thinges se,
Whiche is in all the world so wide.
Whiche forthwith flitteth in the ayre:
That those which certayne here to fore
To death and synne were soulde
By the, and by thy preciouse death
The world vs wronge and wrapt in toyle
The earth obaide their earthlie prince
In mariage knyt from yearthly soyle

div.head: Of his busye and wordly affayers.
div.l: My parents deare in extreame age,
And dolors deape with presence swage,
I se me snaard in sinne
For which lyes ope the pitt of hell
And that drawes me from god
Which I do thinke of dutye well.
And pulls me downe to earth
Who earst in soule to heauen vproose.
Are hartbreake greater then I wist,
They hooly vse eauen as them list,
And to reuenge excesse of lust.
Our Ke •• rs burdens great abroade,
We pricked are as néete with goade.
The richemans fredome from him flyes,
A bout his stocke the chatchpole plyes.
Fatt placed soft one benches hie,
For speady iustyce houle, and crye.
Our casis tiede, as ruled lawe,
Wide nettes they weue, & far them throw.
For this they swéet, and swelt,
For this they taulke, for this they toile,
To treade downe truth for gayne.
By skules they skudde, and rownyng rolle,
To ether part he wil be soulde,
The worst man is the beast
If most he haue to giue of goulde.
Who can go by these trapps?
Who from their snares by sleight can slide,
Onlesse that god become his guide?
He must leaue welth, and wicked gayne:
Or with the soile of synne
His soule, and selfe must totall stayne.
As if thou stand at fyer
Which fast hath spread forth pitchy smoke.
Or stifled sent wil make the choke.

div.head: From Egipt and Babilon to the holie Lande.
div.l: Fly Pharo, and his godlesse prankes:
Leue captyue fieldes, and Babills banks,
In shady places to he founde,
Ne yet their Musickes doolefull sounde.
To retche the bands of hooly land.
When longe thy temple firme may stand▪
Whilst longe I seke it mornyng soore,
A bushe of heare hanges whitly hoore.

div.head: From Sodome to the mounte,
div.l: WHo runnes his race forth right
Thrise happie man of all is he,
For vggly synne lookes backe to se
And postinge hies to mountayne rocke,
Lest he a blocke of salt
Be made, and to the world a mocke.

div.head: Conflict of fleshe and spirit
div.l: AYe me who vnto heauen and saintes
So glad, and fayne would go
But bide in wouen wrethed still
So diuerse is this daungrous life,
I knowe of saftye harbowre none
So soden coursinge cares come on,
My ioye, my comfort and my hart
They eat vp as they feade.
But lose my God, and set me frée
And place me prest amonge thy sainctes

div.head: A brething to God.
div.l: That earth which doth the so impound,
Least that with payes of synne
My carkasse plowng the grouffe to ground
Short is this blisse of life,
As that which dreame a sunder knapps.
Brings heauy heaps of hurtfull haps,
Which aye shalbe, and euer was,
A place of pleasance swete to passe▪

div.head: The world vyolent.
div.l: Why roulst thou me arownde so fast,
I whurled were with whurlewind blast.
Who thoughe it doth with stande it stoute
Is easy drawen, and dragd aboute.
Compact I was of earth and ayre,
My ghost from gods mouth yssude fayre.
Which partly harme me through my fooes,
Doth partly eke increase my wooes.
O world I ende my dayes,
So in the ayre behould I dye.

div.head: Better to dye, or to lyue.
div.l: AS in the ayre the foules,
As in the sea the shipp,
So runne I out my race,
But that which we do sinne,
I like it not to liue,
As ill I like to dye,
My synnes are growen so great
And worse they would me plague
This life is suche a lumpe,
And when thou goost from hence,
Of both sides feare is great,
The beast that I can finde,
Is Christ to fly to the

div.head: Vnlodge the deuill.
div.l: Al spirittes that worke my smart,

div.head: Mortifying.
div.l: With watching much and liuelonge toile
We ought to tame and put to foyle.
Thy selfe to passe contende thou still
Content therfore to be lesse ill:
Those after god will cutt awaye
With payne he will them sharply pay.
So strayt, and narrowe is the gate:

div.head: The felicitie of a Christian is Christ.
div.l: Which in short life is short,
For grownd, and grayne let others prodd,
Their Satten suytes and silkes at nodde.
Whom I in soule may perfitt se,
I pray the take it world to the.

div.head: The life miserable, and synne vnquyet.
div.l: WHy sends thou me o Christ
Within this fleshe my soule to tyre,
And dongeon drent in deadly myre?
If that man be a god
As in some points he is (they saye)
Then, god, I am thy lote,
And sole on the my life doth staye.
My knees haue lost their strength,
And carcke, and heauy frinds make fall,
But me it fast pursues apase,
As when to eat theyr fleshe
The dogge, the Hare, or hart doth chase.
Or me a man forworne sustayne,
And sone acquyt from present payne,

div.head: The vanitie of this lyef A passage vnto God.
div.l: Why bore she me into this wooe.
Alas the day, why did she so?
If that she felt no care,
Nor euer in hir fleshe felt fraye,
But if hir stormes were stearne,
If many tymes, and soore she fought,
(I thinke) that me to world she brought.
All men haue now their trades
And sundry liues they thick pursue,
He shreds the earth with share,
And he with shipp, the waters blue,
And he by plays and prancks
By seafold scornes by termes, and trickes
And fast the fées of men he lickes:
My fée is longe corosyue care,
That maks my carkasse lancke, and spare.
Care cruche me for a tyme
Me cruche and crouse, nor on me rue,
And bidd all care and carke adue.

div.head: The knovvlege of the Trynitie is blesfulnesse:
div.l: That god I can not fully knowe,
Nor eauen so as I would
His prayse I can not full out blowe?
Of Godhead daseleth quyte my brest,
Not fully in my skil doeth reast,
I morne, nor can it perfit fele,
No more then leuen I knowe
Which downe from heauen doth headlong réele.
I face to face shall loke on the
I will not blame my dame,
O happie then, and well is me.
O sonne of god me saue
And take me from this bitter myre,
Of latter life the happy hire:
Wher I shall se the plaine
Thus still suruay the in a cloud.

div.head: A prayer for quiet death.
div.l: KInge Christ the light of men,
And wilsom wander farre, and nye
Do by his hand (o Christ) I praye
Whiche on vs tasks so felly laye.
And from this mud, that doth vs soyle,
Kidd vs, and from this plague,
So full of death, and trudginge toile.
And quyet saffe addresse our waye,
And giue assault to make vs staie,
In hast the read sea swift deuide,
Twixt walles of waues we glade may glyde.
And cuntry coasts that longe shall duer,
Which thou Christ gauste to vs
To haue, and houlde saffe standyng suer.
That true maye be thy worde,
Wherin we only put our trust,
To be more stable, and more iust.
And brokes of pleasance them imbarre,
And dolefull warre set from them farre.
We shal inioy reposd at ease,
We euer will the praise, and pléese.

div.head: Finall repentaunce All is vanitie.
div.l: MY ende of life is come
A shipman I the mayne hath past,
Due for my sinnes a bitter blast.
Now all my crymes must come
And be detected bare in light.
Rue on me Christ, and stand me nye,
And troblouse feares do me agrize
Should fall in wrekful woofull wise.
Fayne would I passe from paynes,
That so my hart consume and eate
And tell you truly as I finde,
There is no profit of this lyfe,
The death ther of doth bring
A lasting life deuoide of strife.

div.head: A repulse to the deuill A passage to heauen A Farewell to the worlde
div.l: A waye thou subtile deuil, and slye
And from my body by and by,
Beast, gaper Dragon, death, and vice,
That into guile dost all intyce.
That dost in murder pleasure much,
With sinne, and death and pestlence such.
Go get the to the seas
Christs so commaunds, or to the rockes
Take vp thy rome in swinishe flockes.
The death of Christ will ells the paye,
That death in all my partes
That death in all my hart doth staye,
The death of Christ is all my ioye,
Surceasse to worke me mor annoye?
Wilt thou not fling the headlong downe
That now for sinne dispeopled towne,
The Godhead great that proude dispise
My hoary head in tempting wise.
Thou makst my mynde both blacke & bloe,
Nor yet for God wilt thou hence gooe?
No more thou canst be gonne thou pelfe,
Thynke not to make me lyke thy selfe.
Nowe must I marche to heauen,
Up to the Threshoulds pure, and fine
My nouell lyfe must shewe, and shine.
Aduaunce I do my heaued hand,
Mongst troups of thine where bright thou stands.
And praye that (world) thou wouldst them spare
World Fare the well, full freyght with care:

div.head: A good beginning, a good endir
div.l: That eche good acte thats well begonne
That doth the ende aduertise the,

div.head: Constancy is crowned.
div.l: A life that had beginning good,
Doth endid bringe an endlesse life,

div.head: Hie speakinge.
div.l: Be furnisht well to speake, or ells▪
In speach mount not to hie:
The bird wil haue hir feathers first,

div.head: Vaine glorie.
div.l: Let not vayne glory moue the ought
Or winde the in with wyle
The simplest man the soner she

div.head: Continuaunce.
div.l: The course lyes easy vnto sinne,
If once thou ginne to slacke.

div.head: Laughter, anger, babling
div.l: Laughe not, controule thyne anger swift,
Thy lipps let them not knowe.

div.head: Dutie to God, parents, preists▪ and Elders.
div.l: Feare god, and to thy parents kinde
Whose heads with hoare do swaye.

div.head: Parentes and Children.
div.l: The sonne with syer to be at lawe,
That wrightings, and that Natures laws

div.head: Suche like.
div.l: What thou in no wise canst abide
That thou in no wise worke, or wishe

div.head: Proportion.
div.l: Great tortour is not great to him,
The lawes do leuye lyke to lyke,
And like to like do lende.

div.head: The tounge.
div.l: A Tounge well spoken vttereth out
The foolyshe mouth doth vtter muche.

div.head: Language.
div.l: Forth out the wise mans wittie mouth,
Forth bitter chaps full brabling words,

div.head: Haples frindles.
div.l: The riche mans house knowes no poore frinde,
The rich mans house is frindly aye
To him that hath as muche.

div.head: Drunkennes.
div.l: Smale single drinke doth not insoft
But bely fat▪ and drunken noule
Doth chaunge the from their kynde.

div.head: A fat belly, a leane vvitt.
div.l: A gorrell paunche, and godly mynde

div.head: Thriftye dyet.
div.l: A dyet thinne doth profit more

div.head: Fooles wise,
div.l: The frantike foole, for dreames doth thinke
Then he which thousandes many one

div.head: Baronnes.
div.l: A baron wombe, then children had
Thus am I sole, but so should I

div.head: A milking sheparde.
div.l: The hungrie pastor let him milke
But for swéet milke in strayning harde
Méere bloud he shall out drawe.

div.head: Order.
div.l: The hogge when he at trowighe doth spye
Betakes him selfe vnto his rome

div.head: Order.
div.l: That they the lawes do right obserue,

div.head: Order.
div.l: Mongst beasts which grouling féede on grounde,
Mongst kenell vile of houling dogges

div.head: Man, death.
div.l: To mortall men cutt of by death
First earth he was, now earth he is,
And him the earth must haue.

div.head: The good feare not.
div.l: Obseruing lawe thou mayst at ease
For he that bideth in the lawe,
In feare neads not to bide.

div.head: VVisdome vanquisheth.
div.l: Both wracke of waue and winde
Gainst haples happe the happie wise

div.head: Perseueraunce.
div.l: Those means eschue whyche leade not to
For errour easy bendes to vyce.

div.head: VVisdome is stronge.
div.l: Not heauie thumpes, or hamers harde
Do moue at all a stithe,
To beare all bruntes a steadfast mynde

div.head: Bugges fraye fooles.
div.l: Eche crackeling lefe the Leueret skars,
And some suche fooles we fynde,
That euery bushe, and euery blast
Doth skarre them from their mynde.

div.head: The poore giuing.
div.l: Those poore I hate to noble men
Who wordes againe, and many wordes,

div.head: The lavvyer
div.l: The wicked Lawyer with his lawe
The law, and realme doth mayme,
The vpright Lawier with his lawe
Doth rule and saue the same.

div.head: The Tutour of the Fatherles.
div.l: The neadles chuffe that laugheth at
Doth laugh at Gods owne vengfull ire,

div.head: The sentence not the vvordes.
div.l: He goose the redyest way of all
Who doth the meanyng of the lawe

div.head: Diuersitie.
div.l: The poore man hath to mynde his meate.
The riche hath muche, and forceth not
But still to more dothe hye.

div.head: Instruction of fooles.
div.l: Thoughe hope be smale, suche hap may be

div.head: Chastninge.
div.l: By stroke of stele the hardest flynte
Is forcd to flynge out fyer,

div.head: An othe
div.l: If thou dost sweare, or if throughe the
Both thou dost ill, and he doth ill,
And both the lawe do teare.

div.head: Treasure.
div.l: Hurde treasure fast, but treasure suche
All worldly treasure in the ende

div.head: Short pleysure.
div.l: Easteme not that, nor compte of it
Which time to the hath brought,
For that which time erected hath,
That time will bringe to nought

div.head: Pleasure chaungable.
div.l: Pleasure is pretye for a tyme
But as she came she ouercasts▪

div.head: Shamefastnesse in vvomen.
div.l: A womans corps, nor mannishe moade

div.head: Helth.
div.l: In sicknesse nought more wishd then helth,

div.head: Bablinge.
div.l: A madd mans wordes are veary like
Which still doth beat vpon the banckes

div.head: Bribes.
div.l: That wyse men arre thats monies worke.
Bribes hath their hart in hould,
A bird is caught with twisted hempe,
A man is caught with gould.

div.head: A sadd spirit.
div.l: Care bringeth age before his tyme,
And that whiche age doth bryng
Before the time, no tract of time

div.head: Riches.
div.l: The seruant swift of vice is welthe,

div.head: Frendeshyp.
div.l: A trustie frinde is treasure best
No person lewde for any cause

div.head: Care.
div.l: The carefull breast deuoures the bones,
Doth kepe the body fat, and fayer

div.head: Temperance in aboundance.
div.l: The meane it can not kepe.
For fyer inflamd, and full in course

div.head: VVyne.
div.l: The mynde, and wyt is feabled sore
For fyer the more that it is fedde

div.head: Feare of iudgement.
div.l: He that of iudgment stands in awe
For those that iudge of wrath it selfe,
In wrathe will iudge the same.

div.head: Affliction to affliction.
div.l: Hard case it is to adde more ill
Yet one ille oft by profe we trye

div.head: Lastinge glorie.
div.l: For that which heare we scrambling k

div.head: Anger an il counsailer.
div.l: That counsaile practise not wher to
For that which wrathe doth counsaile the

div.head: Ill vvomen.
div.l: The dragon hath his noysome ill,
The Adders smart, the Dragons ill,

div.head: Marke the ende.
div.l: The skulles of dead, the heades of quicke
Do proue that that will vs forsake.
For which we carcke, and care.

div.head: Suche father suche child.
div.l: A yonge crabbe if he crepe awrye
Did not the Breader so likwise
What iudge you in this case?

div.head: Like of like.
div.l: When Nature shall reuelt from kynde
Then shall the scholmaister thats badde,

div.head: Gods blessyng.
div.l: If God do lardgly giue increase▪
If god withdrawe his rich increase,

div.head: Order and povver.
div.l: Set more by order then by power,
Uphouldeth power, hath in it selfe,

div.head: Dreading, and melling,
div.l: They that in other matters mell,
In dreadinge daungers not ther owne,

div.head: The lavve of like.
div.l: Why dost thou viper payne abhorre
Assay what throwes had once the wombe

div.head: The stout are gloriouse.
div.l: None euer yet in any world
For conquests stout, and bargings stoute

div.head: Dreames.
div.l: The want of sleape ingenders dreames,
Then slepe that can not spie.
A thinge it self, in vision sées

div.head: Handling of rebelles.
div.l: Force can subdue, and rule prescribe

div.head: The people a beast of many heads.
div.l: The people is of all good thinges

div.head: An ydle worke.
div.l: An Idle worke to be a worke
Which eche wiseman by better right

div.head: Gould a Rethorician.
div.l: If gould come once to speake in place
Thoughe it in speache be dumme.

div.head: VVorldly peace.
div.l: Heare they may liue at their harts ease.
Which dote vpon the wicked world,

div.head: Frinde and fooe.
div.l: A frind by all possible meanes
The fooe is he, that hurts his fooe

div.head: Light shipping.
div.l: Swyme balauncd lightly in the sea,
Do sinke, or brast for weighte

div.head: Musing of death.
div.l: So thou of death, when she shall strike
The lesse of dread shalt haue.

div.head: The mynd a Temple.
div.l: Reare vp to God within thy mynde
So God the Lord, of Heauen, and earth
At home with the will dwell.

div.head: Knowe thy selfe.
div.l: Knowe well thy selfe, and what thou art,
So shalt thou knowe the ofspringe fyrst

div.head: The steadfast mynde.
div.l: The dayes turmoyle vs swift in vayne,
The man of God theternall lighte

div.head: Vanyties.
div.l: On thinges whiche swiftly come and gooe
So mayst thou trust the bubbes of fluddes,

div.head: Deades and woordes.
div.l: Like errour count it to offende
When once thy tounge hath troade awrye

div.head: The path of vertue.
div.l: Tread out the tract of lyfe well leade,
Sincke not but stande vp still,
If thou woulds stande stande not within

div.head: Of sevnge: The stepps of the deuill.
div.l: He seeth not, who séeth not that
That sinne bread smart in space,
We knowe the deuill not by his face,
But note him by hys trace▪

div.head: The sicke man feleth not.
div.l: The pacient sicke his daunger deape
If that he will not tell:
Him vrgent force of present death

div.head: VVordes and vvorkes.
div.l: Let wordes be thyne, and workes be mine,
Standes neade of praising blasing words,

div.head: Idlenes.
div.l: Slouth breadeth lust, and therfore thou
Lest that thy light vnconstant mynde

div.head: Treasure standing.
div.l: Be ryche in God, those riches vayne
Whiche in this world we finde,
Are very like the cobwebbes which

div.head: Vertue passing.
div.l: This world hath naught that worthy is

div.head: Faith.
div.l: Let vs kepe close our faith in hart,
The one is easy washd away,

div.head: The meane.
div.l: Be not to iust, be not to wyse,
Shunne both extreames, and that persue
Which twixt the twayne doth lye.

div.head: Bouldnesse vvith discretion.
div.l: Except thou rule thy stomacke ferce
The discret wyse most worthy things

div.head: Lavve and Lavvyer.
div.l: The lawes of God peruse in brest
So shalt thou be in fee:
Retainde of him whose lawes and sawes

div.head: Please and displease.
div.l: Be good thy selfe, and whom thou oughst
And for to please the godles crue

div.head: VVary in praysing.
div.l: Thy selfe well lyvde, the wicked sort
For all wyl thinke that thyne owne life

div.head: Duresse trieth.
div.l: As golde is tride by flames

div.head: Denying of Father.
div.l: He that his father doth deny
For by the father God did worke

div.head: A good name a good possession.
div.l: Mothes eate vp all: thy goodes with thee
In tumbe shall not be cladde,
At death thyne only honour is
A good name to haue had.

div.head: Spare straungers, and the dead.
div.l: Spare straūgers much, but more thē spare
And left behinde them what they had,

div.head: An other life.
div.l: In Gods name, leaue and quite forsake
And vp to skyes with course direct

div.head: The Trinitie, the fountaine.
div.l: The ishue of all honest actes
From God must haue their course,
The thrise and most blest trinitie

div.head: Mans life.
div.l: When moste it semes to staye
It so muche stayes the lesse,
We holde it but in flight,
Yeat hard at last it slides,
